entry.title: ConveyUX 2014, by Blink
entry.content:
first page of my notes from ConveyUX. all pages in their full nearly-illegible glory at at my tumblr

This past week I attended ConveyUX, a now two-year-old UX conference presented by Blink. I also attended last year, and was impressed by the growth that this conference has had since then. There were over twice the number of attendees, and everyone was incredibly friendly. Don Norman was the keynote speaker and I got him to sign my copy of The Design of Everyday Things!

yess!

I took a lot of notes — not so much to help me remember stuff later (though notes are helpful for that purpose), but because it helps keep my mind from wandering, and helps ideas stick more tightly.

The following are some of the interesting ideas I came away with from the talks I attended.

Day 1 Talks

Keynote, Don Norman

  • UX is not about websites, it's about life.
  • Putting a picture of a button on a screen does not "afford" touching; it "signifies" that the user should touch
  • Designers pride themselves on answering the right question, and not on solving the exact problem they're trying to solve
  • (Don) Norman's Law: the day the product team is assembled, it's over budget and behind schedule. (lolz)
  • The most powerful questions are stupid: question fundamentals and change the world
  • For people struggling with managers, remember: who are your users? It's not the customers. It's the people who are using you, your employers
  • "Marketing was absolutely right to put a button on the radio that was labeled 'better sound,' because otherwise people wouldn't know it was there."

Beyond Usable: Mapping Emotion to Experience, Kelly Goto

  • youyuu: a Japanese idea related to "enjoying the time that you have between events;" for this, you arrive early and cherish the extra time you have
  • "All our fields are moving so fast that we have no youyuu
  • It's powerful to be present
  • Kano surveys: you're not impressed by a cup that doesn't leak, but "not leaking" is necessary to function
  • Kansei engineering: aims the development or improvement of products and services by translating customer's psychological feelings and needs into product design
  • Keep drilling down into user's experiences. Why why why do they enjoy something? What are the "kansei" words?
  • Dscout: see what people are doing on a daily basis
  • Kaizen: continuous improvement — everyday — with everyone — everywhere.

Right Experience, Right People, Phillip Hunter

  • "Have you ever been to a restaurant that was just fine, but you'd never go back?"
  • UX for "real people" is going to the dentist
  • Google "mad at my phone" — there are millions of hits
  • "Experiential equalities must be distinguished from properties of objects" — C. I. Lewis
  • Qualia: intangible things that make up our experience. ex. our responses to color, taste, pain
  • There are no "good" and "bad" words to describe experiences; for example, video games are "hard to use," but this is makes them great games

Beyond Gamification, Catt Small

  • The field is constantly expanding because people are coming in and bringing their previous fields with them
  • Since 2011, more smartphones have sold than computers
  • Game players and game makers connect to each other with easter eggs
  • Zerg Rush!
  • Capitalize on emotions for memorability

Designing for Engagement, Susan Weinschenk

  • People do as little as possible
  • People have a maximum of 20 minutes of thinking time
  • Most mental processing is unconscious — ex. you know what a penny looks like, but wouldn't usually know how to draw one from memory.
  • People can only deal with remembering 3 or 4 things (not 7).
  • More people stopped to see jam when there were 24 jars; but more people BOUGHT jars when there were only 6 displayed.
  • People are more motivated by fear of loss than anticipation of gain.
  • People expect technology to follow human-to-human interaction rules. Thus don't use phrases like "book a copy of the book from the full bib page."

How to Get People to Do Stuff, Susan Weinschenk

  • People's "self stories" govern who they think they are and what they do; so if you want to get them to do something, change those self stories. On that note, words like "Be a Donor" are more effective than "Donate now!"
  • You can tell when someone is doing "slow" thinking — their pupils dilate.
  • People solve logical problems correctly when the problem is written in a hard-to-read font.
  • SALE ON SOUP! If "limit of 10 cans" on the sign, then people buy 7 cans on average; if "no limit" is written, people buy 3.
  • To get people to build a habit around your product, tie it into someone people already do habitually, like checking e-mail in the morning.

Day 2 Talks

Content & Control, Sara Wachter-Boettcher

  • Content reveals a company's values, beliefs, and baggage
  • Don't divide people into "the website team" and "everyone else;" when you let people into the process and help design style guide rules (and such), they get invested, and will actually follow the rules they've made for themselves, rather than the "arbitrary" style and design guides you've imposed on them

What We Can Leaern From Digital Outcasts, Kel Smith

  • People think "accessibility isn't innovative," but what requires more creativity than working underneath extreme constraints? Things like Hummers and Tang have already been created under incredible constraints.
  • The typewriter was invented for a blind person who could not write
  • "The future has arrived, it's just not evenly distributed yet." — William Gibson
  • Competence is a spectrum, not a binary.
  • Empathy allows for you to change "unchangeable" attributes

The Four Most Common Mistakes in Mobile/Web App Designs, Mike Mace

  • DON'T make text too small, older folks can't read it
  • DON'T have low contrast; the sun will wash out words! (For that matter, test your interfaces outside)
  • DON'T use sliders; they're too hard to adjust when there are too many values.
  • Respond fast.
  • Provide help, not tooltips (that people on mobile don't discover as easily)
  • DON'T have an unintuitive success path.
  • Mobile is "short attention span theatre;" people often forget what they're doing or don't understand.

Collaging: Getting Answers to the Questions You Didn't Know to Ask, Kyle Soucy

  • Collaging is a "need evaluation" technique.
  • Honestly, collaging is great and this article describes it better than I could here.

Agile UX: Embrace or Tolerate? Rob Keefer

  • People who struggle with agile dev so do because devs take over and do "cowboy development"
  • Agile is developer-centric. There's little time for design or testing.
  • Remind people to value people over features, feedback over opinion, ease of use over ease of development, discovery over documentation (ex. don't handhold)
  • Doing things together is better!

Day 3 Talks

Writing Great Persona Stories, Whitney Quesenbery

  • Stories are important because they help us remember people who are not in the room.
  • Persona stories help communicate patterns of use
  • If you don't include people with disabilities in the beginning, they're not going to be included later
  • You might know your audience, but do you know how to use your knowledge of them?
  • Make sure your stories are connecting people emotionally to your work. It's the individual story that gets you to donate and work for someone, not the numbers of people that need help.
  • Don't tell stories of how your users are dumb, but of how they accomplish things

Tools for Mobile UX Design, Steven Hoober

  • To design for mobile:
    1. DON'T draw (until you understand your solution). Otherwise, you're going to lock yourself into interactions and events that might not even answer the problem.
    2. Ecosystems first. Figure out your user flows and platforms.
    3. Experience mobile daily. If you're going to design for a Blackberry, get one.
    4. Work at scale. (ex. don't work on mockups that aren't at phone size)
    5. Annotate, describe, understand.
    6. Evaluate (early, as much as you can, before release).
  • Define your design. What are the goals and objectives of your users and organization? What are users doing now to solve the problem you are trying to help them with?
  • If you structure your processes correctly, they will be collaborative.
  • LAUNCH: mobile prototyping
  • Describing is more powerful than prototyping. Specying with words encourages people to design more lightweight-ly. ex. "use default icons" instead of finding logos to display at the right size and color for your prototype
  • Evaluate: Does your information architecture make sense? Are there errors? Is there a "happy path"? ARE YOU LYING?

Anticipatory Services & Ambient Personalisation, Oli Shaw

  • What's our relationship to the invisible services that power our work?
  • "You don't know what's going on in that black box, but install it and we'll give you lower car insurance" — how can this be expanded?
  • Uninvited personalisation is becoming more creepy
  • London trash bins that are tracking wifi-connected smartphones: can tell who you're with, where you work, where you're at....technology is evolving faster than our laws can protect us
  • It's the designer's responsibility to push back and protect users
  • DON'T patronize, obscure, confuse, dictate
  • DO use discretion, appropriate, be relevant, and empathize.
  • Design a relationship, not just an experience.

The World is a Screen, Andrew Hinton

  • "All our cognition is embedded...brains evolved in the service of cognition"
  • "information is elements in the environment that tells us what the environment affords"
  • Perception only exists insofar as we perceive affordances..." You don't perceive anything unless you understand its structure and how to interact with it.
  • Before being literate was a thing, buildings were the way we told stories — cathedrals, gargoyles...
  • The way we talk and write about our shared environment makes that environment. ex. be careful about assuming things like "the TV is the second screen" — this isn't true for everyone.
  • Avocado: an app for couples that lets them send hugs to each other.
  • Check: are the rules behind the environment clearly expressed in its information?

How People Really Touch and Feel, Steve Hoober

  • Mobile traffic outnumbers web traffic
  • "phablet" — a phone tablet. omg
  • People will slow to tap the edges of their phone screen; they are more inaccurate there
  • Make sure your simple interactions just work before moving on to delightful animation
  • Be consistent — make hitboxes conventionally large.
  • A rule of thumb: don't pr stuff about the target below the target, ex. with carousels, don't put labels beneath the pictures because people's thumbs will cover it.
  • Minimum size of hitbox: 6mm. Preferred size: 8mm.
  • Watch out for interference! Make a circle 8mm in diameter and center it on your hitbox. If the circle intersects with other items, those items will interfere.
  • Anything in the edges of the screen or the top and bottom borders should be big.
  • Design by zones. Put things you want people to use on the center.
